content: The threat has been brewing for awhile. Someone should have seen this coming a long time ago. http://forums.military.com/eve/forums/a/tpc/f/672198221...561001#5170083561001 January, 2008 What is a bigger threat – a weak dictator who wants WMDs or the people who attacked America successfully fighting to take over a country that has nuclear weapons? While President Bush has been pre-occupied with Iraq, America’s main enemy has shifted strategy. Iraq is no longer the center of the war on terror. It is now where al Qaeda occupies the attention of more than 150,000 American troops using only a couple thousand of its men. Meanwhile al Qaeda is in the process of taking over a country with nuclear capabilities, and America seems powerless to stop them. >>http://threatswatch.org/rapidrecon/2008/01/alqaedas-open-call-to-jihad-to/ “As the situation in Pakistan continues to deteriorate while al-Qaeda’s insurgency grows stronger and more pervasive, Uzbek Taliiban commander Qadri Tahir Yuldashev released a video message in which he has called for jihad directly against Pakistani military forces. Two al-Qaeda leaders in the north of Pakistan have called on their supporters to wage a new Jihad against security forces and seize control of Islamabad.” “...al-Qaeda’s ultimate target in their insurgency is Islamabad and the complete control of Pakistan, its institutions - including the military and nuclear weaponry - and the institution of Shari’a law, carving out Pakistan as the anchor for the envisioned reestablishment of a caliphate.”
reply: The threat has been brewing for awhile. Someone should have seen this coming a long time ago. http://forums.military.com/eve/forums/a/tpc/f/672198221...561001#5170083561001 January, 2008 What is a bigger threat – a weak dictator who wants WMDs or the people who attacked America successfully fighting to take over a country that has nuclear weapons? While President Bush has been pre-occupied with Iraq, America’s main enemy has shifted strategy. Iraq is no longer the center of the war on terror. It is now where al Qaeda occupies the attention of more than 150,000 American troops using only a couple thousand of its men. Meanwhile al Qaeda is in the process of taking over a country with nuclear capabilities, and America seems powerless to stop them. >>http://threatswatch.org/rapidrecon/2008/01/alqaedas-open-call-to-jihad-to/ “As the situation in Pakistan continues to deteriorate while al-Qaeda’s insurgency grows stronger and more pervasive, Uzbek Taliiban commander Qadri Tahir Yuldashev released a video message in which he has called for jihad directly against Pakistani military forces. Two al-Qaeda leaders in the north of Pakistan have called on their supporters to wage a new Jihad against security forces and seize control of Islamabad.” “...al-Qaeda’s ultimate target in their insurgency is Islamabad and the complete control of Pakistan, its institutions - including the military and nuclear weaponry - and the institution of Shari’a law, carving out Pakistan as the anchor for the envisioned reestablishment of a caliphate.”

content: quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: I am sure that they know how to maintain and use these things, right? My guess is that if (and, that is a big if) they get a hold of one of these as soon as they tinker with one, that whole region will become a sheet of glass. The Taliban would not. The Pakistan nuclear forces would. Their weapons have the same type of positive control that ours do. If the Taliban got ahold of nuclear warheads without the means to detonate them, all they could do with them is use the fissile material inside those warheads to make a dirty bomb. Nuclear warheads don't detonate like conventional high explosives.
quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: I am sure that they know how to maintain and use these things, right? My guess is that if (and, that is a big if) they get a hold of one of these as soon as they tinker with one, that whole region will become a sheet of glass.

content: Yes, I know. There are two ways to detonate a nuc, throwing one radioactive material at another at really high velocity (the easiest way) or crushing it on all sides with equal force and at the same exact time (the method used today). It isn't an easy task by any stretch of the imagination.
